questions.question_text:
In your database, the STATISTICS_LEVEL parameter is set to TYPICAL and an Automatic
Workload Repository (AWR) snapshot is taken every 30 minutes.
Which two statements are true about the Automatic Database Diagnostic Monitor (ADDM)? (Choose two.)

choices.E: It calls other advisors if required, but does not provide recommendations about the advisors to be used.
choices.A: It measures database performance by analyzing the wait time and CPU time of all non-idle user sessions.
choices.D: It requires at least four AWR snapshots for analysis.
choices.C: It runs after each AWR snapshot is created and it requires at least two snapshots for analysis.
choices.B: It always compares the latest snapshot with the baseline snapshot for analysis.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Answer is AB

comments.content:
It also contains static parameters. 
where would they be if not there?

discussion.content:
http://www.dba-oracle.com/concepts/pfile_spfile.htm
I donÂ´t understand because la E is not correct.
where is the fault?
 I Agree A, B

choices.A: An SPFILE can be created from a PFILE or from memory.
choices.C: An SPFILE must reside in the ORACLE_HOME/dbs directory.
choices.D: An SPFILE can be created only before a database instance is started.
choices.B: A PFILE can be used to start up a database instance even if an SPFILE exists.
choices.E: An SPFILE contains only those dynamic parameters that can be changed without having to restart the database instance.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about a server parameter file (SPFILE)? (Choose two.)

Your database is configured in ARCHIVELOG mode, and a daily full database backup is taken by using RMAN. Control file autobackup is configured.
Loss of which three database files can lead to an incomplete recovery? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: Can't be F as controlfile autobackup is on, so we can do media recovery in case of control file backup, won't be incomplete recovery.

comments.content: I agree with dancymonkey. We need inactive Redo logs for media recovery when we restore datafile from backup.

discussion.content:
Why A is not correct? Why C????
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/BRADV/osadvsce.htm#BRADV90048
The log is no longer needed for instance recovery. It may be in use for media recovery, and may or may not be archived
A is not correct. Inactive Redo logs mean they have already been written, and are no longer needed for recovery unless it is media recovery.
A is not correct, instead C is correct.

choices.C: a data file belonging to the SYSAUX tablespace
choices.B: a data file belonging to the default temporary tablespace
choices.A: inactive online redo log file group
choices.E: active online redo log file group

choices.F: Free space in a segment is automatically reclaimed when a resumable statement is suspended because of an out-of-space condition.
choices.A: A database-level LOGON trigger can be used to automatically configure resumable statement settings for individual sessions.
choices.B: SELECT statements that run out of temporary space for sort areas are candidates for resumable execution.
choices.C: A resumable statement can be suspended and resumed only once during a session.
choices.D: Resumable space allocation does not apply when a database instance uses asynchronous commit.
choices.E: Resumable space allocation does not apply when users exceed their assigned space quota in a tablespace.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about resumable space allocation? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Increase the size of the redo log buffer.
choices.A: Increase the size of the temporary tablespace.
choices.D: Enable temporary undo for the database.

discussion.content:
Correct.

"16.7.1 About Managing Temporary Undo
Temporary undo records are stored in the database's temporary tablespaces and thus are not logged in the redo log. When temporary undo is enabled, some of the segments used by the temporary tablespaces store the temporary undo, and these segments are called temporary undo segments.

When temporary undo is enabled, it might be necessary to increase the size of the temporary tablespaces to account for the undo records."

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/undo.htm#ADMIN11478

questions.question_text:
Your database supports an online transaction processing (OLTP) workload in which one of the applications creates a temporary table for a session and performs transactions on it. This consumes a lot of undo tablespace and generates lots of redo.
Which two actions would you take to solve this problem? (Choose two.)
